text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits a revision to IRM 4.24.10, Excise Tax, Appeals Referral Procedures.
Refer to the table below for a detailed list of changes made.
Added guidance referencing IRM

, Early Referral Procedures, as a related resource. Added guidance referencing that the Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) web page is a related resource. Modiﬁed guidance regarding the Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) to comply with suggested terminol- ogy recommended by Internally Managed Documents (IMD).

Description of Change Changed subsection title to Pre- requisites for an Appeals Referral. Incorporated new guidance to include that prior to initiating the appeals referral process, an excise examiner needs to suffi- ciently document the excise case ﬁle. The documentation needs to demonstrate that appeals proce- dures have been explained to the taxpayer and/or taxpayer’s repre- sentative, managerial involvement can be established and the Excise Tax Examination report is accurate. published in April
that itemized the re- quirements to satisfy “adequacy” for formal protests and small case requests.

published in April
that itemized the re- quirements to satisfy “adequacy” for formal protests and small case requests.
Added subsection title Case Routing Procedures for Unagreed Excise Tax Examination Cases to Appeals. Moved and incorporated guidance from IRM
to this subsection. Replaced the electronic link in the prior guidance with the Case Routing into the Independent Office of Appeals electronic link.
Added subsection title Appeals Preconference Procedures. Moved and incorporated guidance from IRM 4.24.10.3.2.
Added subsection title Excise Tax Examination Cases Returned from Appeals. Incorporated guidance from IRM

, Returning a Case to Examination - ATE, concerning situations when Appeals will return an excise case to Excise Tax Examination. Added subsection title Excise Tax Examination Cases Returned from Appeals with New Informa- tion. Incorporated guidance from IRM

excise case with new information is returned from Appeals. Added subsection title Statute of Limitations on Excise Tax Exami- nation Cases Returned from Appeals. Incorporated guidance from IRM

IRM Section Number Description of Change New 4.24.10.11 Added subsection title Closing Agreement and Appeals to Tax Court. Moved and incorporated guidance from IRM 4.24.10.4. New 4.24.10.12 Added subsection title Appeals Feedback Procedures for Excise Tax Examination Cases. Moved and incorporated guidance from IRM 4.24.10.5. Exhibit 4.24.10-1 Acronyms Added ATE to the acronym table. Exhibit 4.24.10-2 Excise Tax - Letter Chart According to Situation Changed subsection title to Letter Table According to Situational Facts and Circumstances. Exhibit 4.24.10-3 Excise Tax - Letter Numbers and Descriptions Changed subsection title to Letter Table - Letter Numbers and De- scriptions. Exhibit 4.24.10-4 Steps and Pro- cedures When a Taxpayer Requests an Appeals Conference Added table referenced under IGM SB/SE 04-0620-0013, Deter- mining the Adequacy of an Appeal in an Excise Tax Case, that identiﬁes the applicable pro- cedures when a taxpayer requests an appeals conference.
Editorial changes have been made when necessary throughout this IRM Section (section) to update electronic links and organizational name changes.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
This material supersedes IRM 4.24.10 dated February 15, 2019, and IGM SB/SE 04-0620-0013, Determining the Adequacy of an Appeal in an Excise Tax Case, dated June 30, 2020.
AUDIENCE

This section contains guidelines and instructions for Excise Tax Examination managers (excise managers), revenue agents and fuel compliance agents (excise examiners) who refer excise tax cases (excise cases) to Appeals.
Table of Contents
Appeals Feedback Procedures for Excise Tax Examination Cases
Acronyms
Steps and Procedures When a Taxpayer Requests an Appeals Conference
Program Owner - Director, Examination - Specialty Examination owns Excise
For stronger compliance, is essential that excise senior management officials, excise managers and excise examiners fully understand the appeals referral
IRC 7803(a)((3) , Execution of duties in accord with taxpayer rights, provides the taxpayer the right to appeal an IRS decision in an independent forum.

Term Deﬁnition 30 Day Letter Written communication issued to the taxpayer that reports the Excise Tax Examination ﬁndings. Appeals Case Memorandum Standardized report issued by Appeals to the ﬁeld that provides feedback on how a referred case was resolved. Ex Parte Communications Any communication between an Appeals employee and a party to a disputed case outside the presence of the opposing party or their representative. To determine whether a communication is ex parte, refer to IRM 4.2.7.2, Deﬁni- tions. Fast Track Settlement (FTS) A jointly administered program offered by IRS to expedite case resolution at the earliest opportu- nity. Formal Written Protest A document prepared for Appeals by the taxpayer and/or the tax- payer’s representative that addresses disputed examination or claim for refund issues if the proposed increase in tax and penalties for any tax period is more than $25,000. Pub 5 provides the required elements for a written protest to be “adequate.”

Any communication between an Appeals employee and a party to a disputed case outside the presence of the opposing party or their representative. To determine whether a communication is ex parte, refer to IRM
, Deﬁni- tions.

A document prepared for Appeals by the taxpayer and/or the tax- payer’s representative that addresses disputed examination or claim for refund issues if the proposed increase in tax and penalties for any tax period is more than $

provides the required elements for a written protest to be “adequate.”

A brief written statement prepared for Appeals by the taxpayer and/or the taxpayer’s representa- tive that lists disputed examination or claim refund issues if the proposed increase in tax and penalties is $
or less for each tax period involved. The reasons supporting the tax- payer’s position are necessary. Pub
provides the required elements for a small case request to be “adequate.”

days remaining on the statute of limitations (SOL) period for assessing excise tax or where the taxpayer did not ﬁle a formal protest or sign an agreement and where proposed additions to tax be assessed. (

Refer to IRM 4.24.21.5.4, Closing Procedures for Unagreed Excise Examina- tions Not to be Forwarded to Appeals, for guidance concerning closing

) Refer to IRM

, Early Referral Procedures, for guidance concerning whereby the excise examiner and the taxpayer are unable to reach an agreement on one or more issues and the taxpayer should be encouraged request early referral of these unagreed issues to Appeals. (

) Moreover, the Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) may be of assistance to taxpayers experiencing economic harm, who are seeking help in resolving problems that have not been resolved through normal procedures or who believe that an IRS system or procedure is not working as designed. Pub

, Taxpayer Advocate Service - We Are Here to Help You, provides contact and additional information. The program is designed to alleviate taxpayer hardships that arise from systemic problems or the application of the Internal Revenue Code. For further guidance, refer to Taxpayer Advocate - Contact (
) The Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) lists rights that already existed in the tax code, putting them in simple language and grouping them into
fundamental rights. Employees are responsible for being familiar with and acting in accord with taxpayer rights. Refer to IRC
). For additional guidance refer the TBOR Website . (

) Prior to forwarding and closing an Excise Tax Examination or claim to Appeals, the excise examiner must conﬁrm the completeness of the case ﬁle. There must be sufficient documentation to establish that: • The procedures for an administrative appeal have been explained to taxpayer or the taxpayer’s representative. Additionally, the option to any deﬁciency and ﬁle a claim for refund, if the taxpayer or the taxpay- er’s representative is not familiar with these procedures, have also explained. • Managerial involvement occurred. The excise case ﬁle must demon- strate that the excise manager was informed when the excise examiner believed a case would have unagreed issues (except for no show or response cases). The excise manager’s actions must be documented the case ﬁle that include attempts to successfully resolve the dispute. Form
, Examining Officer’s Activity Record, may be used for this purpose. Refer to IRM
, Unagreed Closing Procedures. • The Excise Tax Examination report is accurate. For examinations, refer to IRM
, Excise Tax Report Writing Guide. For claims, refer to IRM
, Examination Guidance for Excise Claims for Refund or Abatement. For preparation of workpapers that support accurate exami- nation reports, refer to IRM
, Technical Guidance and Information Processing for Excise Tax Examination Issues, and IRM
, Issue Management System (IMS), Notebook and Workpapers. (
) Excise cases closing to Appeals for the ﬁrst time require at least
days the SOL when they are received in Appeals. Additionally:

must be sufficient documentation to establish that: The procedures for an administrative appeal have been explained to the taxpayer or the taxpayer’s representative. Additionally, the option to pay any deﬁciency and ﬁle a claim for refund, if the taxpayer or the taxpay- er’s representative is not familiar with these procedures, have also been explained. Managerial involvement occurred. The excise case ﬁle must demon- strate that the excise manager was informed when the excise examiner believed a case would have unagreed issues (except for no show or no response cases). The excise manager’s actions must be documented in the case ﬁle that include attempts to successfully resolve the dispute. Form
, Examining Officer’s Activity Record, may be used for this purpose. Refer to IRM
, Unagreed Closing Procedures. The Excise Tax Examination report is accurate. For examinations, refer to IRM
, Excise Tax Report Writing Guide. For claims, refer to IRM
, Examination Guidance for Excise Claims for Refund or Abatement. For preparation of workpapers that support accurate exami- nation reports, refer to IRM
, Technical Guidance and Information Processing for Excise Tax Examination Issues, and IRM

days on
Excise cases closing to Appeals for the ﬁrst time require at least 365 days on the SOL when they are received in Appeals. Additionally:
a. There must be at least

days remaining on the SOL when an excise case is received in Excise Tax Examination, if Appeals returns the excise case for consideration of new information or new issues raised by the taxpayer. b. There must be at least

days remaining on the SOL when an excise case is received in Appeals, if Appeals previously released jurisdiction the excise case and returned it to Excise Tax Examination for additional work. Note: The group must allow a minimum of
days for shipping and pro- cessing an excise case through Technical Services (Tech Services), which will allow for at least
days remaining on the SOL when the case is returned back to Appeals.
) For purposes of excise case processing, the excise examiner should be aware of the
day requirement and plan accordingly when issuing a Letter

Day Letter - Straight Deﬁciency or Over-Assessment for Excise Tax Exami- nation Case, which is a written communication issued to the taxpayer reporting Excise Tax Examination ﬁndings. If the excise case has
days or more remaining on the SOL, the excise examiner should follow the guidance under IRM
, Unagreed Excise Reports, which includes issuing the

Day Letter, if the taxpayer has not expressed agreement. If the excise case is to forward unagreed and the taxpayer wants to exercise their appeal rights, the taxpayer will need to sign a statute extension that allows for sufficient time for preparing the rebuttal, shipping and processing the excise case in Tech Services and allowing for
days on the SOL when it is projected to be received in Appeals. If the excise case has less than
days remaining on the statute, the report should be issued with Letter
-E, Examination Report Transmittal - Statute, or Letter
-A, Examination Report Transmittal - Statute Less Than
Days (Claim), whichever is applicable. Note: The group must allow a minimum of
days for shipping and processing excise case through Tech Services, which will allow for at least
remaining days remaining on the SOL. (

-B, Consent to Extend the Time to Assess Miscellaneous Excise Taxes, is not received, the excise case will be processed based on the proposed changes as an unagreed excise case not eligible for consideration by Appeals. Refer to IRM
, Closing Procedures for Unagreed Excise Examinations Not to be Forwarded to Appeals. Table and (

) Situational facts and circumstances, such as sufficient time being available on the SOL to allow Appeals to review an excise case, determine the appropriate letter to issue with the Excise Tax Examination report. (

day requirement and plan accordingly when issuing a Letter

, Unagreed Excise Reports, which includes issuing the

Day Letter, if the taxpayer has not expressed agreement. days on the SOL when it is projected to be received in Appeals. If the excise case has less than

For purposes of excise case processing, the excise examiner should be aware of the 365 day requirement and plan accordingly when issuing a Letter 950-E, 30 Day Letter - Straight Deﬁciency or Over-Assessment for Excise Tax Exami- nation Case, which is a written communication issued to the taxpayer reporting Excise Tax Examination ﬁndings. If the excise case has 240 days or more remaining on the SOL, the excise examiner should follow the guidance under IRM 4.24.20.3.4, Unagreed Excise Reports, which includes issuing the 30 Day Letter, if the taxpayer has not expressed agreement. If the excise case is to go forward unagreed and the taxpayer wants to exercise their appeal rights, the taxpayer will need to sign a statute extension that allows for sufficient time for preparing the rebuttal, shipping and processing the excise case in Tech Services and allowing for 365 days on the SOL when it is projected to be received in Appeals. If the excise case has less than 240 days remaining on the statute, the report should be issued with Letter 5153-E, Examination Report Transmittal - Statute, or Letter 5153-A, Examination Report Transmittal - Statute Less Than 240 Days (Claim), whichever is applicable.
for Appeals (
) Generally, Appeals procedures for unagreed income tax cases are applicable to excise cases, with the exception of the statutory notice provisions, which do not apply. (

) Unless speciﬁcally excluded from Appeals consideration, all excise cases are eligible to be forwarded to Appeals on the condition that the taxpayer submits an “adequate” protest (when a formal written protest is required) or a small case request that includes the information required under Pub

, Your Appeal Rights and How to Prepare a Protest If You Disagree. Note: Generally, if the taxpayer submits new information or evidence to Appeals or raises a new issue that Excise Tax Examination has not considered, the excise case will be returned. Refer to IRM
, Returning a Case to Ex- amination – ATE, and IRM
, Cases Returned from Appeals. (
) The following is a list of cases that are excluded from Appeals consideration: • Fewer than
days remain on the SOL when the case is received in Appeals. • Request/claim for abatement of unpaid tax that is not an audit reconsid- eration. Refer to IRM

, Claims for Abatement, Audit Reconsiderations, and Supplemental Reports (taxpayer has no judicial rights). • Taxpayer disagrees solely on moral, religious, political, constitutional, conscientious or similar grounds. Refer to IRM
, No Appeals Conference or Concession on Certain Arguments. • Cases designated for litigation. Refer to IRM
, Designating a Case for Litigation. • Cases where Appeals discovered potential fraud, malfeasance or a mis- representation of a material fact. Refer to IRM
for Appeals (
) When the taxpayer requests an Appeals conference, excise examiners must follow the applicable procedures in Exhibit
, Steps and Procedures When a Taxpayer Requests an Appeals Conference.
) The following is a list of cases that are excluded from Appeals consideration: • Fewer than
days remain on the SOL when the case is received in Appeals. • Request/claim for abatement of unpaid tax that is not an audit reconsid- eration. Refer to IRM

, Claims for Abatement, Audit Reconsiderations, and Supplemental Reports (taxpayer has no judicial rights). • Taxpayer disagrees solely on moral, religious, political, constitutional, conscientious or similar grounds. Refer to IRM
, No Appeals Conference or Concession on Certain Arguments. • Cases designated for litigation. Refer to IRM
, Designating a for Litigation. • Cases where Appeals discovered potential fraud, malfeasance or a representation of a material fact. Refer to IRM
) When the taxpayer requests an Appeals conference, excise examiners must follow the applicable procedures in Exhibit
, Steps and Procedures When a Taxpayer Requests an Appeals Conference. (

) Unless speciﬁcally excluded from Appeals consideration, all excise cases are eligible for an Appeals conference if the taxpayer submits an “adequate” written protest (when required) or a small case request. (
) To qualify as “adequate” the taxpayer’s written protest must comply with re- quirements identiﬁed in Pub
, Your Appeal Rights and How To Prepare a Protest if you Disagree. (
) When a rebuttal is needed, the excise examiner will prepare a Form

-A, Explanation of Items. The following areas must be addressed: • Statements, facts and arguments that were not previously explained in the Excise Tax Examination report. • New arguments or facts raised by the taxpayer. • Factual differences between the Excise Tax Examination report and protest. Note: A copy of the rebuttal must be provided to the taxpayer at the time the excise case is sent to Appeals. Excise examiners should use Letter
, Examiner’s Rebuttal, to transmit the rebuttal the taxpayer. Letter
with the attached rebuttal must be
Fewer than
days remain on the SOL when the case is received in Appeals. Request/claim for abatement of unpaid tax that is not an audit reconsid- eration. Refer to IRM

, Claims for Abatement, Audit Reconsiderations, and Supplemental Reports (taxpayer has no judicial rights). Taxpayer disagrees solely on moral, religious, political, constitutional, conscientious or similar grounds. Refer to IRM
, No Appeals Conference or Concession on Certain Arguments. Cases designated for litigation. Refer to IRM
, Designating a for Litigation. Cases where Appeals discovered potential fraud, malfeasance or a representation of a material fact. Refer to IRM
Cases where Appeals discovered potential fraud, malfeasance or a mis- representation of a material fact. Refer to IRM 8.2.1.5.
When a rebuttal is needed, the excise examiner will prepare a Form 886-A, Explanation of Items. The following areas must be addressed:
included with the taxpayer’s protest in the excise case ﬁle as provided in IRM 4.10.9.9.3(1)(e), Forms and Other Documents Inside the Case Folder.
) The protest should be returned to the taxpayer if it does not comply with the requirements as outlined under Pub
and additional time should be granted perfect the protest. Use Letter
-E, Letter of Protest - Excise Tax, or Letter
-A, Letter of Protest (Claims), for this purpose. (
) If a rebuttal is not prepared, when closing the case to Appeals, the excise examiner must prepare Letter
-X, Transfer to Appeals, to notify the taxpayer the case is being closed to Appeals. The letter must be signed by the excise manager and mailed to the taxpayer. (

) A taxpayer’s protest generally will be reviewed at the group level as designated by management within seven calendar days of receipt to determine whether: a. The protest is “adequate.” b. The excise case requires further development by the excise examiner. c. The excise examiner’s report should be modiﬁed. (
) To be considered “adequate,” the taxpayer’s formal protest or small case request must contain all information required under Pub
(with the exceptions noted in the table under Exhibit
, Steps and Procedures When a Taxpayer Requests an Appeals Conference.) (
) A formal written protest is required for a proposed change to the total amount of tax and penalties for any tax period that is more than $
for an increase or decrease in tax and penalties or claimed refund. To meet the Pub

“adequacy” requirement, the formal written protest must include: a. A statement that the taxpayer wants to appeal the changes proposed by the IRS. b. The taxpayer’s name, address and daytime telephone number. c. List of all disputed issues, tax periods or years involved, proposed changes and reasons for the taxpayer’s disagreement with each issue. d. Facts supporting the taxpayer’s position on each disputed issue. e. Law or authority, if any, supporting the taxpayer’s position on each disputed issue. f. A declaration of truth under penalties of perjury. This may be done by adding the following signed declaration to the protest document: “Under penalties of perjury, I declare to the best of my knowledge and belief, that the information contained in this protest and accompanying documents is true, correct and complete.” (

) If the taxpayer’s representative submits the written protest for the taxpayer, the representative must substitute a declaration stating: a. That the protest and accompanying documents were submitted by the representative. b. That to the best of their personal knowledge and belief, the information true, correct and complete or, if not, there is no personal knowledge con- cerning the information stated in the protest and accompanying documents. Internal Revenue Manual
A taxpayer’s protest generally will be reviewed at the group level as designated by management within seven calendar days of receipt to determine whether:
) A formal written protest is required for a proposed change to the total amount of tax and penalties for any tax period that is more than $
for an increase or decrease in tax and penalties or claimed refund. To meet the Pub

“adequacy” requirement, the formal written protest must include: a. A statement that the taxpayer wants to appeal the changes proposed by the IRS. b. The taxpayer’s name, address and daytime telephone number. c. List of all disputed issues, tax periods or years involved, proposed changes and reasons for the taxpayer’s disagreement with each issue. d. Facts supporting the taxpayer’s position on each disputed issue. e. Law or authority, if any, supporting the taxpayer’s position on each disputed issue. f. A declaration of truth under penalties of perjury. This may be done by adding the following signed declaration to the protest document: “Under penalties of perjury, I declare to the best of my knowledge and belief, that the information contained in this protest and accompanying documents is true, correct and complete.” (

) If the taxpayer’s representative submits the written protest for the taxpayer, the representative must substitute a declaration stating: a. That the protest and accompanying documents were submitted by the representative. b. That to the best of their personal knowledge and belief, the information true, correct and complete or, if not, there is no personal knowledge con- cerning the information stated in the protest and accompanying documents.

A statement that the taxpayer wants to appeal the changes proposed by the IRS. The taxpayer’s name, address and daytime telephone number. List of all disputed issues, tax periods or years involved, proposed changes and reasons for the taxpayer’s disagreement with each issue. Facts supporting the taxpayer’s position on each disputed issue. Law or authority, if any, supporting the taxpayer’s position on each disputed issue. A declaration of truth under penalties of perjury. This may be done by adding the following signed declaration to the protest document: “Under penalties of perjury, I declare to the best of my knowledge and belief, that the information contained in this protest and accompanying documents true, correct and complete.”
If the taxpayer’s representative submits the written protest for the taxpayer, the representative must substitute a declaration stating:

a. That the protest and accompanying documents were submitted by the representative. b. That to the best of their personal knowledge and belief, the information is true, correct and complete or, if not, there is no personal knowledge con
cerning the information stated in the protest and accompanying documents.
c. The taxpayer or the representative must sign the document under the penalties of perjury statement. (
) If the total amount of tax and penalties is $
or less, the taxpayer may submit a small case request. To meet the Pub

“adequacy” requirement, the small case request should include: • A brief written statement listing the disputed issues and why the taxpayer disagrees with the proposal for more tax and penalties, or • A completed appeal request form, Form
, Statement of Disputed Issues, that was included with the letter the taxpayer received proposing the change, if applicable, or a completed Form
, Request for Appeals Review. (

) “Adequacy” of a protest is generally not determined based on substantive content, such as whether the protest contains sufficient factual or legal support. If a taxpayer submits a formal written protest that includes all the information required by Pub
addressing the issues raised in the

Day letter, the reasons for disagreement and factual information to support their position on the issues, then the excise case must be forwarded for Appeals consideration. This is regardless whether the excise examiner or excise manager disagrees with the taxpayer’s facts and/or does not consider the taxpayer’s position suffi- ciently supported. (
) An incomplete protest, which is one that does not satisfy the requirements listed in Pub

, must be returned to the taxpayer and additional time granted perfect the document. If the protest contains information warranting further consideration, the excise case should be returned to the excise examiner for further development. Excise cases returned for additional development should be considered priority work and given expedited consideration. (

) If the excise examiner or excise manager determines there is something in the protest that does not change the determination but requires further comment explanation and is not conﬁdential in nature, a rebuttal can be prepared and included in the excise case ﬁle before being sent to Appeals. This rebuttal will serve to supplement the information contained within the excise examiner’s report and offer a constructive response to the taxpayer’s arguments that were presented in the protest. If a rebuttal is prepared, the taxpayer must be provided a copy. Excise examiners should use Letter
, Examiner’s Rebuttal, for this purpose. (
) The excise manager is authorized to meet with the taxpayer to discuss any disputed issues in an attempt to resolve them, obtain taxpayer agreement and limit taxpayer burden. Tax to (
) Appeals has specially trained Appeals Officers (AOs) who handle excise tax cases referrals. Note: Dyed diesel penalty cases may be assigned to non-excise cadre members. (
) All unagreed excise cases are routed to Appeals via Tech Services. a. In the “Forward to Technical Services” section of Form
, Special Handling Notice for Examination Case Processing, the boxes “Unagreed to Appeals” and “Other” must be checked.

The taxpayer or the representative must sign the document under the penalties of perjury statement.
Note: Dyed diesel penalty cases may be assigned to non-excise cadre members.
All unagreed excise cases are routed to Appeals via Tech Services.
In the “Forward to Technical Services” section of Form
, Special Handling Notice for Examination Case Processing, the boxes “Unagreed to Appeals” and “Other” must be checked.
b. In the “Other” section of Form
, the excise examiner will refer to the “Case Routing Addresses and Information” instructions shown at the In- dependent Office of Appeals, Case Routing web site. (
) In an unnamed section on Form
below the “Other” section, check the box for “Forward to Tech Services - Update to Status
” Enter the “Date Closed to Manager” and “Manager Name.” (
) After the physical excise case ﬁle is mailed to Tech Services, the excise examiner will close the case off IMS.
Note: The AO can view an excise case closed off IMS once it is assigned to them.

) If the taxpayer requests a transfer of jurisdiction for an appeal and the written protest is “adequate,” the excise case ﬁle will be routed to Appeals. (

If Appeals cannot resolve the excise case to the taxpayer’s satisfaction, the taxpayer’s only recourse will be paying the additional tax when assessed and

ﬁling a claim for refund within the applicable SOL. Upon disallowance of the claim or six months from the date the claim was ﬁled, the taxpayer may then ﬁle suit in the U.S. District Court or the U.S. Court of Federal Claims to recover the excise tax paid. (

) After giving the taxpayer or the taxpayer’s representative an opportunity to par- ticipate, a preconference meeting may be held between the Appeals Officer (AO) and the excise examiner. This may be about a protested excise case ad- dressing an unusual or complex issue. A determination regarding what is an unusual or complex issue will be left to the discretion of the AO and the excise examiner. (

) The purpose of a preconference meeting is to discuss the issue, the protest and the written rebuttal in an excise case containing a complex or unusual issue. A frank discussion of the issue will help to identify additional information that may be needed on the issue. The need for resources, specialists or expert witnesses, etc., can be discussed at this preconference meeting. Excise Tax Examination is encouraged to share its views on disputed issues, including the assessment of the facts and the law to recommended adjustments on a par- ticular issue. However, the preconference meeting is not for securing a commitment from Appeals to defend a particular issue or settlement position, or otherwise negotiate the settlement posture of Appeals on an excise case. (
) A preconference meeting will take place prior to an Appeals/taxpayer confer- ence. (

) If a preconference meeting is requested by the excise examiner and/or the excise manager, the request should accompany the excise case ﬁle when sent to Appeals. The request must be conveyed in a written memorandum and signed by the excise manager and must be associated with the excise case ﬁle. (

) Review of taxpayer’s formal protest and preparation of the rebuttal in non- docketed cases: a. Before forwarding the excise case to Appeals, the excise examiner must review any new information, new issue or new argument raised by the taxpayer or the taxpayer’s representative in the protest to determine Excise Tax Examination’s position before preparing a written rebuttal. The rebuttal is not intended to restate positions taken in the Excise Tax Ex- amination report, but to address any new information or new issues raised in the protest. A copy of the excise examiner’s rebuttal will be provided to the taxpayer and/or the taxpayer’s representative before sending the excise case to Appeals for consideration. b. The protest rebuttal shall reference the request for a preconference meeting and refer to the separate request memorandum from the excise manager. This will alert the AO to look for the preconference meeting request memorandum. c. Factual differences between the Excise Tax Examination report and the protest will be reconciled. Rebuttals will be secured from specialists, such as engineers, economists, appraisers, etc., who provided background data, assumptions, etc., used to formulate Excise Tax Examination’s position. These reports will be included in the administrative ﬁle with the protest and provided to the taxpayer or representative before sending the excise case to Appeals for consideration.
Excise Tax

ﬁling a claim for refund within the applicable SOL. Upon disallowance of the claim or six months from the date the claim was ﬁled, the taxpayer may then ﬁle suit in the U.S. District Court or the U.S. Court of Federal Claims to recover the excise tax paid.

a. Before forwarding the excise case to Appeals, the excise examiner must review any new information, new issue or new argument raised by the taxpayer or the taxpayer’s representative in the protest to determine Excise Tax Examination’s position before preparing a written rebuttal. The rebuttal is not intended to restate positions taken in the Excise Tax Ex

amination report, but to address any new information or new issues raised in the protest. A copy of the excise examiner’s rebuttal will be provided to the taxpayer and/or the taxpayer’s representative before sending the excise case to Appeals for consideration. b. The protest rebuttal shall reference the request for a preconference meeting and refer to the separate request memorandum from the excise manager. This will alert the AO to look for the preconference meeting request memorandum. c. Factual differences between the Excise Tax Examination report and the protest will be reconciled. Rebuttals will be secured from specialists, such as engineers, economists, appraisers, etc., who provided background data, assumptions, etc., used to formulate Excise Tax Examination’s position. These reports will be included in the administrative ﬁle with the protest and provided to the taxpayer or representative before sending the excise case to Appeals for consideration.

d. Excise Tax Examination will seek technical advice on a novel or unique issue prior to Appeals’ consideration. e. Changes in the excise examiner’s and the excise manager’s position made during the review process will be reﬂected clearly in any revised report and will include any tax re-computations. Note: The excise examiner should not wait until the taxpayer disagrees to secure technical advice or reports from specialists to prepare for the preconference meeting. Doing so might delay the taxpayer’s appeal and limit the time the taxpayer has to respond. If the excise examiner has such information that addresses the taxpayer’s arguments, the information must be provided to taxpayer with the
Day Letter, to assist the taxpayer in the decision of whether to retain an expert or professional to prepare a rebuttal. (

) If a preconference meeting initiated by either party is accepted by the other party, the acceptance need not be in writing, but the acceptance should be communicated expeditiously to the other party. (
) A request by either party shall address the unusual or complex factual or issue warranting the preconference. (
) Either the AO or excise examiner can decline the preconference meeting request. The declination must be in writing and signed and conveyed to the other party with copies to respective managers. (
) Despite these preconference meeting procedures, the AO remains responsible for complying with the SOL procedures outlined in IRM
, Appeals Statute Responsibility. (

) Participation in a preconference meeting: a. The AO will arrange the meeting. b. Appeals and Excise Tax Examination will each identify its participants the meeting. c. The participants may include other specialists, as deemed necessary Excise Tax Examination. d. The parties will determine the location and method of the preconference on a case-by-case basis. (
) Appeals will return excise cases to Excise Tax Examination in the following situations (not all-inclusive): • Missing protest. • Inadequate protest (does not meet the requirements described in Pub
). • Less than

days remaining on the SOL. • Taxpayer provides new information or evidence. • Taxpayer raises new issues not considered by Excise Tax Examination. • Contrary to IRS practice, the excise case is a reopening of a previously closed excise case as set forth in Rev. Proc.

• The excise case involves claims for abatement of excise tax or trust fund recovery penalty which are not deemed meritorious by IRS. • Appeals discovers potential fraud, malfeasance or misrepresentation a material fact. Refer to IRM
, Returning a Case to Examination - ATE. Procedures

) Excise Tax Examination Cases Returned from Appeals with New Information (

) In some situations, the taxpayer may provide new information or new evidence related to a disputed issue that was not previously shared with the excise examiner. If the Appeals hearing officer believes the information merits addi- tional analysis or investigative action by Excise Tax Examination, Appeals will release jurisdiction and return the excise case to the excise examiner to evaluate and make an audit determination. Refer to IRM
, Cases Returned from Appeals, for more detailed guidance.
) Statute of Limitations on Excise Tax Examination Cases Returned from Appeals (
) If the taxpayer raises a relevant new issue and there will be less than
days remaining on the SOL when the originating function receives the excise case, Appeals will not return the excise case unless the taxpayer provides a consent to extend the SOL. Refer to IRM
, Taxpayer Raises New Issue, for more detailed guidance. (
) If Appeals previously released jurisdiction of the excise case and returned it Excise Tax Examination for additional work, there must be at least
days remaining on the SOL when the excise case is received in Appeals the second time. The group must allow a minimum of
days for shipping and processing an excise case through Tech Services. Therefore,
days must be remaining on the SOL when the excise case is closed from the group.
) Undeveloped Excise Tax Examination Cases (

) Appeals will not return excise cases to Excise Tax Examination when they not fully developed and the taxpayer has not presented new information or evidence. Instead, Appeals will attempt to settle the excise case on factual hazards. Refer to IRM
, Cases Not Fully Developed, for more detailed guidance.
) Closing Agreement and Appeals to Tax Court (
) IRM
, Processing Closing Agreements in Appeals, contains guidance instructions regarding closing agreements under IRC
, Closing agree- ments, for all types of taxes. (
) The United States Tax Court has no jurisdiction over cases involving the excise taxes reported on Form
, Quarterly Federal Excise Tax Return, Form
, Heavy Highway Vehicle Use Tax Return, Form
, Monthly Tax Return for Wagers, and Form

-C, Occupational Tax and Registration Return for Wagering. After payment of at least a divisible portion of the excise tax, these cases may be litigated in either the United States District Court or the United States Court of Federal Claims by ﬁling a suit for refund of the excise tax
) Appeals Feedback Procedures for Excise Tax Examination Cases (

through the formal dissent procedures. Formal dissent procedures are found in IRM

, Disagreements with Appeals Determinations. The formal dissent procedures are not intended to replace any informal procedures currently in use. It is expected that Excise Tax Examination, Excise Tax Policy and Appeals will continue to address and resolve disagreements over excise case resolutions at the lowest possible level. The formal dissent procedures are used when the informal process results in Excise Tax Examination or Excise Tax Policy continuing to have not resolved signiﬁcant concerns about the Appeals disposition of an issue. Note: Formal dissents will not generally be appropriate in an Appeals case where “hazards of litigation” were considered in the settlement of the excise case or in excise cases resolved by applying “judgment”, unless such judgment is clearly erroneous. (
) Dissents will be prepared by Excise Tax Policy and forwarded to the appropri- ate Appeals area director, through the Excise Tax Policy - Program Manager within
days (extensions may be mutually agreed upon) of receipt by Excise Tax Examination of an ACM. Refer to IRM

for detailed dissent routing guidance. Excise Tax Policy and Appeals may also hold post settlement conferences. The purpose of the post settlement conference is to discuss the settlement reached and its subsequent impact on the taxpayer. The post settle- ment conference is not intended to be a critique of the settlement nor is it intended to replace dissent procedures.

through the formal dissent procedures. Formal dissent procedures are found in IRM 8.6.4.2.10, Disagreements with Appeals Determinations. Steps and Procedures When a Taxpayer Requests an Appeals Conference

When the taxpayer requests an Appeals conference, excise examiners must follow the applicable procedures in table below: If Then (a) The total amount of tax and penalties for any tax period is not more than $25,000. Note: In computing the total amount, include a proposed increase or decrease in tax (including penalties), or claimed refund. The taxpayer may make a small case request instead of ﬁling a formal written protest. The taxpayer may complete Form 12203, Request for Appeals Review, or Form 13683, Statement of Disputed Issues. Note: Pub 5 contains instructions on preparing formal written protests and small case requests in unagreed excise cases. (b) The total amount of tax and penalties for any tax period is more than $25,000. Note: In computing the total amount, include a proposed increase or decrease in tax (including penalties) or claimed refund. The taxpayer must submit a formal written protest. Note: Pub 5 contains instructions about preparing formal written protests and small case requests in unagreed excise cases. (c) The taxpayer submits a formal written protest or small case request. The protest must be reviewed at the group level, as designated by management, within seven days of receipt to determine whether the protest complies with the requirements identiﬁed in Pub 5. The protest review should include consideration of any new facts, laws or arguments presented to determine if: • The excise case requires further develop- ment by the excise examiner. • The excise examiner’s report should be modiﬁed. • The excise examiner should write a rebuttal to refute arguments in the protest.
When the taxpayer requests an Appeals conference, excise examiners must follow the applicable procedures in the table below:

contains instructions about preparing formal written protests and small case requests in unagreed excise cases.

(c) The taxpayer submits a formal written protest or small case request.
The excise case requires further develop
ment by the excise examiner. The excise examiner’s report should be modiﬁed. The excise examiner should write a rebuttal to refute arguments in the protest.
The protest should be returned to the taxpayer and additional time should be granted to perfect the protest. The excise examiner should use one of the following letters for this purpose: • Letter
, Letter of Protest • Letter
-A, Letter of Protest (Claims) • Letter
-B, Letter of Protest (No-Change with Adjustments) Note: If the only item missing from the protest is a copy of the

Day letter, the excise case can be closed using the copy in the ﬁle, therefore, there is no need to return the protest to the taxpayer for perfection. The excise case may require additional develop- ment because of additional facts raised and/or new information, issues or legal arguments presented in the formal written protest or small case request. Excise cases requiring additional development are priority work and should be given expedited con- sideration. Refer to IRM

, Timely Actions - Request for an Appeals Conference. Reminder: Generally, Appeals does not return excise cases for further development unless the taxpayer provides new in- formation or evidence to Appeals or raises a new issue Excise Tax Exami- nation has not considered. A rebuttal should be prepared and included in the excise case ﬁle before it is sent to Appeals. Refer to IRM
) for additional guidance on preparing a rebuttal.

A rebuttal should be prepared and included in the excise case ﬁle before it is sent to Appeals. Refer to IRM 4.24.10.5(5) for additional guidance on preparing a rebuttal.

-A or Letter

Transfer of protest cases to Appeals is generally excluded except for:

excluded except for: Other taxable periods of the same taxpayer not listed on the notice. Other types of tax for the same taxable periods for the same taxpayer, which are not listed on the notice. An offer in compromise covering the same type of tax and the same taxable periods of the taxpayer.
